conversation.content: ecrit moi 53 quêtes secondaires avec les informations suivantes : un jeune heros amerindien part à la recherche d’un arc et une fleche magique pour ensuite aller tuer le dieu de la luxure qui se reveille a l’interieur d’une lointaine montagne. sur sa route il trouvera une femme et un homme qui deviendront ses alliés. l histoire se passe dans la foret amazonienne. chaque mission principales doit se passer dans une commune de guyane française. une des misssions principal sera un labyrinthe. il rencontra plusieurs personne lié a l histoire guyanaise et devra les aidés

9. Réparer un vieux pont en bois qui permet de traverser une rivière dangereuse.
10. Trouver de la nourriture pour les habitants d'une petite communauté affamée.
11. Chasser un serpent géant qui a attaqué des villageois.
12. Trouver des moyens de protéger les cultures locales contre les insectes nuisibles.
13. Rassembler des matériaux pour construire des abris plus résistants pour la communauté.
14. Sauver des oiseaux rares d'un groupe de braconniers qui veulent les capturer.
15. Trouver des moyens de renforcer la sécurité de la communauté contre les animaux sauvages.
16. Rassembler des informations sur un groupe de trafiquants de drogue dans la région.
17. Protéger les habitants contre les attaques de pillards d'une tribu rivale.
18. Explorer une zone dangereuse connue pour abriter des esprits maléfiques.
19. Trouver une relique mystique pour aider à protéger la communauté contre les mauvais esprits.
20. Collecter des informations sur les pratiques de chamanisme dans la région.
21. Trouver des moyens de protéger les rivières locales contre la pollution.
22. Sauver un aigle blessé et le ramener à la santé.
23. Trouver des moyens de prévenir les glissements de terrain dans une zone dangereuse.
24. Découvrir les secrets d'une vieille mine abandonnée dans la région.
25. Trouver une source d'énergie alternative pour la communauté qui s'appuie actuellement sur des générateurs bruyants et polluants.
26. Faire face à un groupe de braconniers qui abattent des animaux protégés dans la région.
27. Gérer une épidémie de malaria qui sévit dans la région.
28. Trouver des moyens de prévenir les incendies de forêt dans la région.
29. Sauver un groupe de personnes coincées dans une grotte inondée.
30. Trouver des moyens de prévenir l'érosion du sol des cultures.
31. Contrer les tentatives d'un grand groupe de trafiquants de drogue à étendre leurs opérations dans la région.
32. Aidé une vieille dame à retrouver sa famille après avoir été séparée lors d'un vol.
33. Accomplir un rituel de guérison pour aider un shaman local à se remettre de sa maladie.
34. Fendre un bloc de pierre et ramener les morceaux pour la construction d'une petite église.
35. Sauver une famille menacée par une coulée de boue en raison des fortes pluies dans la région.
36. Trouver des solutions pour protéger les eaux contre la pollution venant des exploitations minières.
37. Faire face à un groupe d'autochtones qui menacent de faire la guerre à la communauté.
38. Trouver l'origine d'un étrange phénomène de meurtres dans la région.

40. Trouver des moyens de protéger les arbres tropicaux de la région et la biodiversité qu'elle abrite.

42. Traquer le responsable de l'incendie qui a ravagé la forêt.

Can you write these instructions again without conflict between them and more clearly?
choose option 8 if
- Caller doesn’t reach a qualified agent.
- Caller is left on hold or reaches voicemail.
- Call connection lost or wrong number dialed.
- Caller doesn’t reach the desired person, leaves or declines to leave a message.
- Caller hangs up during the greeting.
- Call consists only of fax machine sounds or similar noises.

choose option 7 if
- General, non-service-related conversation.
- The service requested is not offered.
- Caller inquires about recalls, and there are none.
- Call is about parts only, no service mentioned.
- Caller only asks about a car wash.
- Caller discusses a bill without mentioning services.
- Call intended for the body shop or collision center (separate from service).

choose option 6 if
- Caller discusses a vehicle in service or additional services.
- The call is about the status of a vehicle already in service

choose option 5 if
- Discussing existing appointment, cancels or reschedules an appointment that was already scheduled for an upcoming time.

choose option 4 if
- Service inquiry without discussing appointment details.

choose option 1 if
- Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time.
- Caller provides loose time range, agent sets specific time. Example: “I can be there between 2:00 and 4:00. I’ll put you down for 3:00, and then if you show up a little earlier or later, that’s fine.”
- Caller schedules appointment, plans to drop off vehicle early.
- Caller agrees to an approximate time of “around 1 hour” or less
- Caller discusses an existing appointment and agrees to a new appointment

choose option 2 if
- Vague knowledge to possibly visit.
- Caller agrees to come in with an imprecise time range exceeding 1 hour
- Caller agrees to come in before or after a specific time.
- First come, first served knowledge
- Unscheduled walk-in knowledge
- Caller agrees to come in at a certain time, but no appointment time is guaranteed.
- No appointment necessary.
- Visit or walk-in time window exceeds 1 hour.
- Drop-off with unscheduled appointment.

choose option 3 if
- Caller inquires about a service appointment without confirming one.
- Agent suggests or mentions a visit, but without confirming appointment.
- An appointment is mentioned but not set

Select option 8 when:
- The caller doesn't connect with a qualified agent.
- A caller is left on hold, reaches voicemail, or the call is lost.
- The wrong number is dialed or the desired person is not reached.
- The call ends during the greeting.
- The call consists of non-verbal sounds, such as fax machine sounds.

Choose option 7 when:
- The conversation does not involve a specific service.
- The requested service is not available.
- Recall inquiries, parts-only inquiries, or car wash inquiries are made.
- The call is regarding billing issues or collision center matters without mentioning services.

Select option 6 when:
- The caller discusses an ongoing service or additional services.
- The call concerns the status of a vehicle already in service.

Select option 5 when:
- An existing appointment is discussed, rescheduled, or canceled.

Choose option 4 when:
- The caller inquires about a service without discussing appointment details.

Select option 1 when:
- An appointment is confirmed with a specific date and time or loose time range.
- The caller agrees to an unscheduled appointment with an approximate duration of 1 hour or less.

Choose option 2 when:
- The caller expresses interest in dropping by the service center with an imprecise time range or general intention to visit.
- Walk-in or first-come-first-served scenarios arise.
- The caller agrees on a time, but it's not guaranteed.

Choose option 3 when:
- The caller asks about a service appointment without scheduling one.
- An agent mentions a visit, but the appointment is not confirmed.
- An appointment is discussed but not set.

Does the previous answer fit these options? if not, modify it to fit more:
Option 1. Specific appointment or walk-in time / range within 1 hour
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time.
Example call - Caller: "I need a tune-up."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in at 11:45 tomorrow morning."// Caller: "Perfect. I'll see you then!"// Call ends.
Caller approximates a loose time range, but the agent puts down a firm time for the appointment. In these instances, the agent’s statement trumps the caller's.
Example - Caller: "I can be there between 2:00 and 4:00." // Agent: "I'll put you down for 3:00, and then if you show up a little earlier or later, that's fine."
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time but plans to drop the vehicle off before the scheduled appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need an oil change."// Agent: "I will schedule you for 10:00 AM tomorrow."// Caller: "Can I drop my car off before my appointment?" // Agent: "Yes, you can drop your car off any time, and just leave your keys in the drop box."// Caller: "Great, thanks!" // Call ends.
Caller agrees to an approximate time within a 1 hour time range because they are able to be serviced at the time of arrival.
A walk-in time within an hour range, for a vehicle that can be serviced immediately, should be considered a specific appointment time. This is true because, even if an appointment is not put on the schedule, the service shop has an expected arrival time for the caller and the service can be completed at that arrival time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my brakes repaired. Do you have any openings today?"// Agent: "You can come in now if you'd like"// Caller: "Great! I'll be there in half an hour." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "My car is being towed there right now and should be there in about 20 minutes. Can it be looked at right away?" // Agent: "Yeah, that's no problem. We'll look at it as soon as it arrives."
Caller agrees to an approximate time of "around 1 hour".
Caller discusses an existing appointment and agrees to a new appointment during the same call.
Example call - Caller: "I'm checking on the status of my car that's in service, and I also wanted to know if I could bring my wife's car in for an oil change."// Agent: "Your car is ready to be picked up, we can get your wife's car in at 4:00 if that time works for you."// Caller: "That works. We'll be there at 4:00."
Option 2. Unscheduled walk-in or loose appointment time / range exceeding 1 hour
Caller gives a vague agreement to possibly come in.
Example call - Caller: Do you have availability tomorrow morning. // Agent: "Yes, we're pretty open all morning." // Caller: "Okay, I may drop it off in the morning." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to come in but approximates a time range that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "I'll be there in about 2 hours."
Caller agrees to come in before or after a specific time.
Example call - Caller: "I can be there sometime before 4:00 PM."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime before 4:00, making this a loose appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I won't be able to get there until after 5:00."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime after 5:00.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that it is first come, first served and the caller says "OK."
Example call - Caller: "Do I need an appointment for an oil change?"// Receptionist or agent: "It is first come, first served."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
Caller agrees to be an unscheduled walk-in.
Example call - Caller - "Do you accept walk-ins?" // Agent: "We'll be accepting walk-ins all day Saturday." // Caller: "I'll be there sometime Saturday then!"
Caller agrees to come in at a certain time but no appointment time is guaranteed.
A walk-in time within an hour range, that can be serviced immediately, is a specific appointment time. However, a specific walk-in time with no specific service time cannot be considered a specific appointment, because the vehicle cannot be serviced immediately upon arrival. In the following example, the caller gives a specific arrival time, but the service time cannot be set for a specific time. Thus, it is a soft appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my car serviced as soon as possible." // Agent: "We're all booked through the whole week." // Caller: "Can I just come in and have my car serviced between other appointments?" // Agent: "You can come in and possibly have your car serviced if they have time, but we cannot guarantee a service time and you may be here for a few hours." // Caller: "I'll just get there when you open tomorrow at 8:00, and I'll wait."
Caller is having his or her vehicle towed in but no appointment time is guaranteed.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that no appointment is necessary, they can just show up.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my tire rotated today?" // Receptionist or agent: "Absolutely. You don't need an appointment. Just come on in."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
The time of the visit or walk-in is for a window of time that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "My check engine light is on and I'd like to come in to have it checked out." // Agent: "No problem. Can you come in today? We have openings after 12pm" // Caller: "Yeah, I'll be there between 12:30 and 2:30." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to drop off his or her vehicle for an unscheduled appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my car in for service tomorrow?" // Agent: "What time do you need it done?" // Caller: "Anytime is fine. I'll just drop it off at 7:00 and leave it there for the day." // Agent: "Great, we'll get it done before the end of the day."
Option 3. Appointment requested / mentioned but not set
Caller asked about a service appointment but did not agree to an appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need to bring my car in for some routine service."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in tomorrow morning."// Caller: "That won't work for me. I need to get it serviced today." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my motor oil replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Price is provided and appointment requested. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I'm not interested. Thanks."
Option 4. No appointment, walk-in, or drop-off discussed
Caller is asking about a service or there was an opportunity to book an appointment but no appointment, walk-in, or drop-off was discussed.
Example call - Caller: "Does your service department do oil changes?"// Receptionist or agent: "Yes"// Caller: "Thanks." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my fluids flushed and replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Only the price is provided and NO potential appointment is mentioned. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I’m not interested. Thanks."
Option 5. Upcoming scheduled appointment
Caller discusses an existing appointment already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Caller cancels or reschedules an appointment that was already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Option 6. Vehicle already in service
Caller discusses or asks about the status of a vehicle already in service.
Caller adds services to a vehicle already in service.
Option 7. No, not an appointment opportunity
Call is general conversation, a personal call, or employee-to-employee conversation and no appointment opportunity exists.
The service requested is not offered by the dealership/shop/business.
Caller asks if there are any recalls and is told there are no open recalls.
Caller asks if vehicle is due for service and is told the vehicle is not due for service.
Call is about parts only and there is no service mentioned.
Caller is only discussing a bill without any discussion of services.
Caller is only asking about a car wash without any discussion of services.
Caller asks how to service something on their own and services are not needed from the service shop.
Example: "Can you tell me how to reset the code in my door panel?" // Agent provides instructions over the phone. No appointment is requested/needed.
Call is intended for the body shop. The body shop is a separate department from service.
Call is intended for the collision center. The collision center is a separate department from service.
Option 8. Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent
Caller never connected to a live, qualified agent.
Caller is left on hold.
Call connection was lost and no contact information was shared and/or no appointment discussion took place.
Caller reached voicemail.
Caller had the wrong number.
Caller did not reach the desired person and left a live message.
Caller did not reach the desired person and declined to leave a live message.
Caller hung up during the bridge greeting.
Call only consists of fax machine sounds or other similar noises.

Select option 1 for specific appointments or walk-in time/range within 1 hour when:
- The caller confirms an appointment with a specific date and time.
- A loose time range is given, but a specific appointment is set.
- The caller intends to drop off the vehicle before the appointment.
- An approximate time within a 1-hour range for immediate service is confirmed.
- An existing appointment is discussed, and a new appointment is agreed upon.

Choose option 2 for unscheduled walk-ins or a loose appointment time/range exceeding 1 hour when:
- The caller vaguely agrees to visit without specifying an appointment time.
- The time range provided exceeds 1 hour.
- The caller agrees to come before or after a specified time.
- A first-come, first-served situation is acknowledged by the caller.

Select option 3 for appointment requests or mentions without booking when:

Choose option 4 when no appointment, walk-in, or drop-off is discussed, and inquiries are only service-related.

Select option 5 for existing or scheduled appointments when:

Choose option 6 for vehicles already in service when:
- The caller discusses a vehicle currently in service or requests additional services.

Select option 7 when there is no appointment opportunity, such as:
- General conversation or non-service-related inquiries.
- The requested service is not offered or relevant.
- The discussion is about billing, car washes, or parts only.

Choose option 8 when the caller never connects with a live, qualified agent or:
- The caller is left on hold, the call is lost or disconnected, or voicemail is reached.
- The wrong number is dialed, or the desired person is not reached.
- The phone call ends during the greeting or only contains non-verbal noises.
Can you turn the previous answer into a prompt for chatgpt? so that it reads the transcript of a call and classifies it according to the previous instructions

I'm assuming you'd like to create a ChatGPT prompt based on the categories described in the previous response. Here's an example of a prompt you can use to instruct ChatGPT:

"Given the transcript of a phone call between a customer and a service center, classify the call according to the following categories:

1. Specific appointment or walk-in time/range within 1 hour
2. Unscheduled walk-in or loose appointment time/range exceeding 1 hour
3. Appointment requested/mentioned but not set
4. No appointment, walk-in, or drop-off discussed
5. Upcoming scheduled appointment
6. Vehicle already in service
7. No appointment opportunity
8. Caller never connected to a live, qualified agent

Please read the transcript below and determine which category best applies:

[insert transcript here]

Based on the provided transcript, which category does this call belong to?"

Replace "[insert transcript here]" with the actual call transcript before sending it to ChatGPT. The AI will process the transcript and provide an appropriate classification based on the categories defined in the previous response.
Can you add a little more explanatory detail to the categories?

Of course, here is an expanded version of the categories with more explanatory details:

1. Specific appointment or walk-in time/range within 1 hour:
The caller schedules an appointment with a specific date and time, or they agree to walk-in within a 1-hour time frame. This category also includes discussions about existing appointments that result in new appointments being confirmed.

2. Unscheduled walk-in or loose appointment time/range exceeding 1 hour:
The caller agrees on an unscheduled walk-in or provides a loose time range that's longer than 1 hour for a planned visit. There might be no guarantee for an exact appointment time, and callers might acknowledge first-come, first-served scenarios.

3. Appointment requested/mentioned but not set:
The caller inquires about an appointment but doesn't confirm a specific appointment time. In this situation, the appointment is mentioned or requested, but no definitive plans are made.

4. No appointment, walk-in, or drop-off discussed:
The conversation focuses on service-related inquiries, but there's no discussion regarding appointments, walk-ins, or vehicle drop-offs. It includes conversations about pricing, services available, and other related information without scheduling a visit.

5. Upcoming scheduled appointment:
The caller discusses an existing appointment that has already been scheduled for an upcoming time and date. It may involve the caller rescheduling or canceling the appointment.

6. Vehicle already in service:
The discussion concerns a vehicle already in service. Callers ask about the status of their vehicle, seek updates, or request additional services while their vehicle is in the service center.

7. No appointment opportunity:
Conversations that don't present potential appointment opportunities fall into this category. These calls may involve general conversations, discussions about services not offered, inquiries about recalls or car washes, or billing issues without mentioning service requests.

8. Caller never connected to a live, qualified agent:
The caller doesn't manage to connect with a qualified representative during the call. This category covers scenarios where the caller is left on hold or reaches voicemail, a connection is lost or the wrong number is dialed, or the intended person isn't reached. It also includes calls that end during the greeting or contain non-verbal noises such as fax machine sounds.

Category Instructions: Service Setter Booked
The purpose of the category Service Setter Booked is to determine if the caller represents a service appointment opportunity and if an appointment was booked during the call.

Helpful information:
Qualified agent: An employee that is able to assist a caller with his or her inquiry. The qualified employee may at times need to call back in order to provide an answer or solution. As long as the same employee is the one intending to return the call, it is still considered connected.
Unqualified agent: An employee that is not able to assist the caller with his or her inquiry. A caller may reach an unqualified employee and hold a conversation, but it is not considered a connected call unless the caller is connected to someone who can assist him or her with their inquiry.
Appointment opportunity: Connected calls about potential maintenance or repair service(s) the shop can perform, repair or installation of a part that the shop can perform, or confirmed open recalls that the service shop can perform.
Service opportunities include but are not limited to:
Oil changes
Fluid flushes
Key programming / key cutting / key battery replacement
Part installation
Tire installation
Battery installation
Car detailing
Call types that should NOT be considered service:
Body work or collision repair
Car washes
Finance, sales, etc.
Interactive systems and auto-attendants: Calls handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant will sound like interactive recordings that ask questions or request information and require the caller to interact by making phone selections. When a call is successfully handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant it should be considered a connected call, and proper review selections should be made according to the content and outcome of the call. When a caller leaves a call back number with the interactive system, instead of successfully handling their inquiry or need, then the call should be considered not connected.
Reminders:
Calls in this category need to be reviewed based on this category's instructions. Overview instructions for other appointment related categories do not apply to this category.
The service appointment time should be considered the time the vehicle can be serviced.
Here are the options:
Option 1. Specific appointment or walk-in time / range within 1 hour
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time.
Example call - Caller: "I need a tune-up."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in at 11:45 tomorrow morning."// Caller: "Perfect. I'll see you then!"// Call ends.
Caller approximates a loose time range, but the agent puts down a firm time for the appointment. In these instances, the agent’s statement trumps the caller's.
Example - Caller: "I can be there between 2:00 and 4:00." // Agent: "I'll put you down for 3:00, and then if you show up a little earlier or later, that's fine."
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time but plans to drop the vehicle off before the scheduled appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need an oil change."// Agent: "I will schedule you for 10:00 AM tomorrow."// Caller: "Can I drop my car off before my appointment?" // Agent: "Yes, you can drop your car off any time, and just leave your keys in the drop box."// Caller: "Great, thanks!" // Call ends.
Caller agrees to an approximate time within a 1 hour time range because they are able to be serviced at the time of arrival.
A walk-in time within an hour range, for a vehicle that can be serviced immediately, should be considered a specific appointment time. This is true because, even if an appointment is not put on the schedule, the service shop has an expected arrival time for the caller and the service can be completed at that arrival time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my brakes repaired. Do you have any openings today?"// Agent: "You can come in now if you'd like"// Caller: "Great! I'll be there in half an hour." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "My car is being towed there right now and should be there in about 20 minutes. Can it be looked at right away?" // Agent: "Yeah, that's no problem. We'll look at it as soon as it arrives."
Caller agrees to an approximate time of "around 1 hour".
Caller discusses an existing appointment and agrees to a new appointment during the same call.
Example call - Caller: "I'm checking on the status of my car that's in service, and I also wanted to know if I could bring my wife's car in for an oil change."// Agent: "Your car is ready to be picked up, we can get your wife's car in at 4:00 if that time works for you."// Caller: "That works. We'll be there at 4:00."
Option 2. Unscheduled walk-in or loose appointment time / range exceeding 1 hour
Caller gives a vague agreement to possibly come in.
Example call - Caller: Do you have availability tomorrow morning. // Agent: "Yes, we're pretty open all morning." // Caller: "Okay, I may drop it off in the morning." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to come in but approximates a time range that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "I'll be there in about 2 hours."
Caller agrees to come in before or after a specific time.
Example call - Caller: "I can be there sometime before 4:00 PM."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime before 4:00, making this a loose appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I won't be able to get there until after 5:00."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime after 5:00.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that it is first come, first served and the caller says "OK."
Example call - Caller: "Do I need an appointment for an oil change?"// Receptionist or agent: "It is first come, first served."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
Caller agrees to be an unscheduled walk-in.
Example call - Caller - "Do you accept walk-ins?" // Agent: "We'll be accepting walk-ins all day Saturday." // Caller: "I'll be there sometime Saturday then!"
Caller agrees to come in at a certain time but no appointment time is guaranteed.
A walk-in time within an hour range, that can be serviced immediately, is a specific appointment time. However, a specific walk-in time with no specific service time cannot be considered a specific appointment, because the vehicle cannot be serviced immediately upon arrival. In the following example, the caller gives a specific arrival time, but the service time cannot be set for a specific time. Thus, it is a soft appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my car serviced as soon as possible." // Agent: "We're all booked through the whole week." // Caller: "Can I just come in and have my car serviced between other appointments?" // Agent: "You can come in and possibly have your car serviced if they have time, but we cannot guarantee a service time and you may be here for a few hours." // Caller: "I'll just get there when you open tomorrow at 8:00, and I'll wait."
Caller is having his or her vehicle towed in but no appointment time is guaranteed.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that no appointment is necessary, they can just show up.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my tire rotated today?" // Receptionist or agent: "Absolutely. You don't need an appointment. Just come on in."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
The time of the visit or walk-in is for a window of time that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "My check engine light is on and I'd like to come in to have it checked out." // Agent: "No problem. Can you come in today? We have openings after 12pm" // Caller: "Yeah, I'll be there between 12:30 and 2:30." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to drop off his or her vehicle for an unscheduled appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my car in for service tomorrow?" // Agent: "What time do you need it done?" // Caller: "Anytime is fine. I'll just drop it off at 7:00 and leave it there for the day." // Agent: "Great, we'll get it done before the end of the day."
Option 3. Appointment requested / mentioned but not set
Caller asked about a service appointment but did not agree to an appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need to bring my car in for some routine service."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in tomorrow morning."// Caller: "That won't work for me. I need to get it serviced today." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my motor oil replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Price is provided and appointment requested. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I'm not interested. Thanks."
Option 4. No appointment, walk-in, or drop-off discussed
Caller is asking about a service or there was an opportunity to book an appointment but no appointment, walk-in, or drop-off was discussed.
Example call - Caller: "Does your service department do oil changes?"// Receptionist or agent: "Yes"// Caller: "Thanks." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my fluids flushed and replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Only the price is provided and NO potential appointment is mentioned. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I’m not interested. Thanks."
Option 5. Upcoming scheduled appointment
Caller discusses an existing appointment already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Caller cancels or reschedules an appointment that was already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Option 6. Vehicle already in service
Caller discusses or asks about the status of a vehicle already in service.
Caller adds services to a vehicle already in service.
Option 7. No, not an appointment opportunity
Call is general conversation, a personal call, or employee-to-employee conversation and no appointment opportunity exists.
The service requested is not offered by the dealership/shop/business.

Option 8. Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent

Category Instructions: Service Setter Booked

The purpose of this category is to determine if the caller represents a service appointment opportunity and if an appointment was booked during the call.

Definitions:
- Qualified agent: An employee who can assist a caller with their inquiry. A qualified employee may need to call back to provide a solution or answer, but this is still considered a connected call as long as the same employee initiates the return call.
- Unqualified agent: An employee who cannot assist the caller with their inquiry. A conversation with an unqualified employee is not considered a connected call unless the caller is connected to someone who can assist with their inquiry.
- Appointment opportunity: Connected calls discussing potential maintenance or repair services, part installation or replacements, and confirmed open recalls that the service shop can perform. Service opportunities can include oil changes, fluid flushes, key programming/cutting, part or tire installation, battery installation, and car detailing. Calls related to body work, car washes, and finance or sales should not be considered service opportunities.
- Interactive systems and auto-attendants: Calls handled by interactive recordings asking questions and requiring phone selections. Calls successfully handled by these systems should be considered connected calls, but calls with only a callback number left for the system should be considered not connected.

Options for Service Appointment Outcomes:
1. Specific Appointment or Walk-In Time/Range within 1 Hour
- Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time, or a loose time range set by the agent.
- Caller agrees to a specific date and time but plans to drop off their vehicle before the appointment.
- Caller agrees to an approximate time within a 1-hour range because their vehicle can be serviced upon arrival.
- Caller agrees to drop off their vehicle at an unscheduled appointment time.

2. Unscheduled Walk-In or Loose Appointment Time/Range Exceeding 1 Hour
- Caller gives a vague agreement to possibly come in, exceeding a 1-hour time range.
- Caller agrees to come in before or after a specific time, with no guaranteed appointment time.
- Receptionist or agent tells the caller it's a first-come, first-served basis.
- Caller agrees to be an unscheduled walk-in.
- Caller agrees to drop off their vehicle for an unscheduled appointment time.

3. Appointment Requested/Mentioned but Not Set
- Caller asked about a service appointment but did not agree to an appointment.

4. No Appointment, Walk-In, or Drop-Off Discussed
- Caller asks about a service, but no appointment, walk-in, or drop-off discussion occurs.

5. Upcoming Scheduled Appointment
- Caller discusses their existing appointment, cancellation, or rescheduling.

6. Vehicle Already in Service
- Caller discusses or asks about a vehicle already in service.

7. No Appointment Opportunity
- Calls are general conversation, personal, employee-to-employee, or not related to offered services.

8. Correction: Caller Never Connected to a Live, Qualified Agent
- Caller never connected to a qualified agent for various reasons, such as being left on hold, reaching voicemail, or having the call connection lost.

Las tres opciones son distintas formas en que un cliente puede solicitar un servicio en un centro de atención. 

La opción 1 se refiere a llamadas en las que los clientes acuerdan una cita específica en una fecha y hora determinadas, o indican un rango de tiempo y acuerdan una hora fija para la cita. También se incluyen llamadas en las que los clientes discuten una cita existente y acuerdan una nueva durante la misma llamada.

La opción 2 se refiere a llamadas en las que los clientes acuerdan una hora de llegada vaga o una hora de cita que excede una hora. También se incluyen llamadas en las que los clientes aceptan que el servicio se preste según el orden de llegada, sin una cita específica, o dejan su vehículo para una cita no programada. Los clientes también pueden acordar una hora de llegada específica, pero sin una hora de servicio garantizada, lo que se considera una hora de cita flexible.

La opción 3 se refiere a llamadas en las que los clientes solicitan una cita para un servicio, pero no confirman la cita. Estas llamadas pueden incluir a los clientes que solicitan información sobre un servicio, pero no acuerdan una cita. También se incluyen llamadas en las que los clientes solicitan una cita, pero no confirman la hora de la cita ofrecida o declinan hacer una cita después de escuchar el precio del servicio.
Cual es la diferencia entre las 3 opciones anteriores?

La principal diferencia entre estas opciones es cómo el cliente acuerda una cita o solicita un servicio. 

La opción 1 se enfoca en clientes que acuerdan una cita específica en una fecha y hora determinadas o una cita dentro de un rango flexible de 1 hora. En esta opción, se puede discutir una cita existente y acordar una nueva.

La opción 2 se refiere a clientes que acuerdan una hora de llegada vaga o su vehículo para una cita no programada en una fecha futura. También se pueden acordar citas, pero sin una hora de servicio garantizada.

La opción 3 se refiere a clientes que solicitan una cita para un servicio, pero no la confirman por algún motivo. En esta opción, los clientes pueden solicitar información y precios, pero no comprometerse a una cita o pueden solicitar una cita, pero no aceptar la propuesta del centro de servicio.

En resumen, la principal diferencia entre las opciones es cómo el cliente solía pedir una cita o solicitar un servicio, desde opciones específicas y fijas hasta opciones más flexibles o sin confirmación.

conversation.content:
Seleccione la categoría que mejor describa el resultado de la llamada en términos de programación de servicios y/o acuerdos de citas/citas.

Categoría 1: Si el cliente programa una cita para un tiempo específico o acuerda en llegar dentro de una hora o menos. Por ejemplo, ‘Puedo programar una cita para el lunes a las 9:00 AM’ o ‘Llegaré allí en 30 minutos para una cita’.

Categoría 2: Si el cliente llega sin cita previa o acuerda un tiempo aproximado de llegada que excede una hora o acuerda una posible visita o cita de manera vaga. Por ejemplo, ‘Podría estar allí en algún momento esta tarde’ o ‘Estoy pensando en traer mi automóvil para una revisión, tal vez lo haga esta semana’.

Categoría 3: Si el cliente pregunta sobre la disponibilidad de citas o servicios y se habla sobre una cita o visita pero no se confirma. Por ejemplo, ‘¿Tienen horarios disponibles para un cambio de aceite?’ o ‘Estoy interesado en un servicio, ¿podrían darme más detalles?’

Categoría 4: Si el cliente solo hace preguntas sobre el servicio sin pedir una cita. Por ejemplo, ‘¿Cuáles son los servicios que ofrecen?’

Categoría 5: Si el cliente ya tiene una cita programada o discute una cita ya existente. Por ejemplo, ‘Necesito cambiar la fecha de mi cita para otra semana’.

Categoría 6: Si el cliente pregunta acerca del estado del vehículo mientras está siendo reparado o solicita servicios adicionales durante el tiempo que ya está siendo reparado. Por ejemplo, ‘¿Cómo va el trabajo en mi vehículo? ¿Tengo que arreglar algo más?’

Categoría 7: Si la llamada es una conversación general no relacionada con ninguna cita o servicio programado, si el cliente pregunta acerca de las partes solamente sin mencionar servicios o si el servicio requerido no es ofrecido. Por ejemplo, ‘¿Tienen esta pieza en stock?’ o ‘¿Puedo comprar una batería para mi auto aquí?’

Categoría 8: Si no hay comunicación con un agente calificado. Por ejemplo, si la llamada se cortó antes de hablar con un representante o si se mantuvieron en espera durante mucho tiempo sin respuesta.

como puedo mejorar el promp para evitar este error y que no haya conflicto entre las categorias?

También puedes considerar especificar aún más los criterios de cada categoría, para que no haya lugar a interpretaciones ambiguas. 

Por ejemplo, en la Categoría 3 puedes añadir ejemplos más precisos de lo que significa "hablar sobre una cita o visita, pero no confirmar", como "preguntar sobre la disponibilidad de fechas y horarios, pero no llegar a programar una cita específica". 

Además, puedes ofrecer una breve descripción de cada categoría antes de presentar los ejemplos, para que los usuarios tengan una visión general y sepan qué buscar en cada una. 

Con estos ajustes, es más probable que los usuarios seleccionen la categoría correcta y se minimicen los errores y confusiones en la clasificación de las llamadas.

Given the transcript of a phone call between a customer and a service center, classify the call according to the following options:

Helpful information:
Qualified agent: An employee that is able to assist a caller with his or her inquiry. The qualified employee may at times need to call back in order to provide an answer or solution. As long as the same employee is the one intending to return the call, it is still considered connected.
Unqualified agent: An employee that is not able to assist the caller with his or her inquiry. A caller may reach an unqualified employee and hold a conversation, but it is not considered a connected call unless the caller is connected to someone who can assist him or her with their inquiry.
Appointment opportunity: Connected calls about potential maintenance or repair service(s) the shop can perform, repair or installation of a part that the shop can perform, or confirmed open recalls that the service shop can perform.
Service opportunities include but are not limited to:
Oil changes
Fluid flushes
Key programming / key cutting / key battery replacement
Part installation
Tire installation
Battery installation
Car detailing
Call types that should NOT be considered service:
Body work or collision repair
Car washes
Finance, sales, etc.
Interactive systems and auto-attendants: Calls handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant will sound like interactive recordings that ask questions or request information and require the caller to interact by making phone selections. When a call is successfully handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant it should be considered a connected call, and proper review selections should be made according to the content and outcome of the call. When a caller leaves a call back number with the interactive system, instead of successfully handling their inquiry or need, then the call should be considered not connected.
Reminders:
Calls in this category need to be reviewed based on this category's instructions. Overview instructions for other appointment related categories do not apply to this category.
The service appointment time should be considered the time the vehicle can be serviced.
Here are the options:
Option 1. Specific appointment or walk-in time / range within 1 hour
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time.
Example call - Caller: "I need a tune-up."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in at 11:45 tomorrow morning."// Caller: "Perfect. I'll see you then!"// Call ends.
Caller approximates a loose time range, but the agent puts down a firm time for the appointment. In these instances, the agent’s statement trumps the caller's.
Example - Caller: "I can be there between 2:00 and 4:00." // Agent: "I'll put you down for 3:00, and then if you show up a little earlier or later, that's fine."
Caller agrees to an appointment with a specific date and time but plans to drop the vehicle off before the scheduled appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need an oil change."// Agent: "I will schedule you for 10:00 AM tomorrow."// Caller: "Can I drop my car off before my appointment?" // Agent: "Yes, you can drop your car off any time, and just leave your keys in the drop box."// Caller: "Great, thanks!" // Call ends.
Caller agrees to an approximate time within a 1 hour time range because they are able to be serviced at the time of arrival.
A walk-in time within an hour range, for a vehicle that can be serviced immediately, should be considered a specific appointment time. This is true because, even if an appointment is not put on the schedule, the service shop has an expected arrival time for the caller and the service can be completed at that arrival time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my brakes repaired. Do you have any openings today?"// Agent: "You can come in now if you'd like"// Caller: "Great! I'll be there in half an hour." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "My car is being towed there right now and should be there in about 20 minutes. Can it be looked at right away?" // Agent: "Yeah, that's no problem. We'll look at it as soon as it arrives."
Caller agrees to an approximate time of "around 1 hour".
Caller discusses an existing appointment and agrees to a new appointment during the same call.
Example call - Caller: "I'm checking on the status of my car that's in service, and I also wanted to know if I could bring my wife's car in for an oil change."// Agent: "Your car is ready to be picked up, we can get your wife's car in at 4:00 if that time works for you."// Caller: "That works. We'll be there at 4:00."
Option 2. Unscheduled walk-in or loose appointment time / range exceeding 1 hour
Caller gives a vague agreement to possibly come in.
Example call - Caller: Do you have availability tomorrow morning. // Agent: "Yes, we're pretty open all morning." // Caller: "Okay, I may drop it off in the morning." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to come in but approximates a time range that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "I'll be there in about 2 hours."
Caller agrees to come in before or after a specific time.
Example call - Caller: "I can be there sometime before 4:00 PM."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime before 4:00, making this a loose appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I won't be able to get there until after 5:00."
In this example, the caller could be there anytime after 5:00.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that it is first come, first served and the caller says "OK."
Example call - Caller: "Do I need an appointment for an oil change?"// Receptionist or agent: "It is first come, first served."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
Caller agrees to be an unscheduled walk-in.
Example call - Caller - "Do you accept walk-ins?" // Agent: "We'll be accepting walk-ins all day Saturday." // Caller: "I'll be there sometime Saturday then!"
Caller agrees to come in at a certain time but no appointment time is guaranteed.
A walk-in time within an hour range, that can be serviced immediately, is a specific appointment time. However, a specific walk-in time with no specific service time cannot be considered a specific appointment, because the vehicle cannot be serviced immediately upon arrival. In the following example, the caller gives a specific arrival time, but the service time cannot be set for a specific time. Thus, it is a soft appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "I need to get my car serviced as soon as possible." // Agent: "We're all booked through the whole week." // Caller: "Can I just come in and have my car serviced between other appointments?" // Agent: "You can come in and possibly have your car serviced if they have time, but we cannot guarantee a service time and you may be here for a few hours." // Caller: "I'll just get there when you open tomorrow at 8:00, and I'll wait."
Caller is having his or her vehicle towed in but no appointment time is guaranteed.
Receptionist or agent tells the caller that no appointment is necessary, they can just show up.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my tire rotated today?" // Receptionist or agent: "Absolutely. You don't need an appointment. Just come on in."// Caller acknowledges this and the call ends.
The time of the visit or walk-in is for a window of time that exceeds 1 hour.
Example call - Caller: "My check engine light is on and I'd like to come in to have it checked out." // Agent: "No problem. Can you come in today? We have openings after 12pm" // Caller: "Yeah, I'll be there between 12:30 and 2:30." // Call ends.
Caller agrees to drop off his or her vehicle for an unscheduled appointment time.
Example call - Caller: "Can I get my car in for service tomorrow?" // Agent: "What time do you need it done?" // Caller: "Anytime is fine. I'll just drop it off at 7:00 and leave it there for the day." // Agent: "Great, we'll get it done before the end of the day."
Option 3. Appointment requested / mentioned but not set
Caller asked about a service appointment but did not agree to an appointment.
Example call - Caller: "I need to bring my car in for some routine service."// Receptionist or agent: "We can fit you in tomorrow morning."// Caller: "That won't work for me. I need to get it serviced today." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my motor oil replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Price is provided and appointment requested. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I'm not interested. Thanks."
Option 4. No appointment, walk-in, or drop-off discussed
Caller is asking about a service or there was an opportunity to book an appointment but no appointment, walk-in, or drop-off was discussed.
Example call - Caller: "Does your service department do oil changes?"// Receptionist or agent: "Yes"// Caller: "Thanks." // Call ends.
Example call - Caller: "I want to get my fluids flushed and replaced. How much do you charge for that?" // Only the price is provided and NO potential appointment is mentioned. // Caller: "Oh, that's too much. I’m not interested. Thanks."
Option 5. Upcoming scheduled appointment
Caller discusses an existing appointment already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Caller cancels or reschedules an appointment that was already scheduled for an upcoming time and/or date.
Option 6. Vehicle already in service
Caller discusses or asks about the status of a vehicle already in service.
Caller adds services to a vehicle already in service.
Option 7. No, not an appointment opportunity
Call is general conversation, a personal call, or employee-to-employee conversation and no appointment opportunity exists.
The service requested is not offered by the dealership/shop/business.
Caller asks if there are any recalls and is told there are no open recalls.
Caller asks if vehicle is due for service and is told the vehicle is not due for service.
Call is about parts only and there is no service mentioned.
Caller is only discussing a bill without any discussion of services.
Caller is only asking about a car wash without any discussion of services.
Caller asks how to service something on their own and services are not needed from the service shop.
Example: "Can you tell me how to reset the code in my door panel?" // Agent provides instructions over the phone. No appointment is requested/needed.
Call is intended for the body shop. The body shop is a separate department from service.
Call is intended for the collision center. The collision center is a separate department from service.
Option 8. Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent
Caller never connected to a live, qualified agent.
Caller is left on hold.
Call connection was lost and no contact information was shared and/or no appointment discussion took place.

Category Instructions: Dealership Discussion
The purpose of the category Dealership Discussion is to determine what the caller is discussing with the dealership.


Helpful information:
Connected calls:
Calls must be considered connected to be reviewed in this category. If the call does not qualify as connected, the correction option should be selected to remove the call from the category. A call is considered connected when the caller has either reached the desired agent or reached a qualified agent that can assist the caller.
Qualified agent:
A qualified agent is an employee that can assist a caller with most or all of his or her inquiry. The qualified agent may at times be too busy to handle the inquiry at the time of the call, or he or she may need to gather more information and call back to provide an answer or solution. These scenarios are still considered connected to a qualified agent if the same agent is the one intending to return the call.
Unqualified agent:
An unqualified agent is an employee that is not able to assist the caller with most or all of his or her inquiry either during that specific call or in a promised follow-up call from the same agent.
Interactive systems and auto-attendants:
Calls handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant will sound like interactive recordings that ask questions or request information and require the caller to interact by making phone selections. These can be either Connected or Not Connected.
When a call is successfully handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant it should be considered a connected call, and proper review selections should be made according to the content and outcome of the call.
When a caller leaves a call back number with the interactive system, instead of successfully handling their inquiry or need, then the call should be considered not connected.
Here are the options:
Opportunity to buy/sell/lease/trade a vehicle
Call represented an opportunity for the dealership to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle
The call does not have to include the mention of a particular make or model.
Some opportunities to buy, sell, lease, or trade may at times only mention vehicle specs. These should be listened to carefully to determine if there is an opportunity for the dealership to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle.
All calls that include a caller's interest in buying, selling, leasing, or trading a vehicle should be reviewed with this option, even if the vehicle is not currently available.
Caller inquiries about a vehicle of interest
This may include but is not limited to inquiries about vehicles seen online, in an advertisement, or from driving past the dealership's lot.
Caller expresses general interest in vehicle inventory
This may include but is not limited to inquiries regarding what vehicles are available that fit the caller's price range or what vehicles meet certain desired criteria.
Call is about payment or financing options for the purchase of a vehicle
This does not include calls regarding the financing of a vehicle that is already in the caller's possession.
Caller is inquiring about leasing a vehicle or is interested in a lease buyout
Caller would like to sell or trade a vehicle to the dealership
Caller is another dealership that represents an opportunity to buy or sell a vehicle
This does not include conversations about dealer trades. Dealer trades are not opportunities for a dealership to buy or sell a vehicle. Dealer trades, sometimes also referred to as dealer swaps, are when competing dealerships trade cars with each other, swapping similar cars to meet the demands of their customers. These are exchanges of vehicles only, and they do not represent buying or selling.
Service / parts / collision / body shop
Call is regarding automotive service
This may include but is not limited to service department hour inquiries, general service questions, service needs, service appointments, or inquiring about the status of a vehicle that is already being serviced by the dealership.
Call is regarding automotive parts
This may include but is not limited to parts department hour inquiries, general parts questions, part orders, or price and installation inquiries.
Call is regarding automotive collision or the body shop
This may include but is not limited to collision or body shop department hour inquiries, general collision or body shop questions, price and repair inquiries, and collision or body shop appointments.
General / caller not in market / dealer trade
Caller has general questions or a general conversation that does not represent an opportunity for the buying, selling, or trading of a vehicle
Caller is inquiring about the status of a vehicle order that has already been placed
Caller is inquiring about the delivery of a vehicle they have already purchased
Caller is from a transport company delivering a vehicle or multiple vehicles
Call is about financing and there was no opportunity for the buying, selling, or trading of a vehicle
Call is about the refinancing of a vehicle that is already in the caller's possession
Call is about the payments for a vehicle that is already in the caller's possession
Caller only states that they are coming to the dealership to drop off paperwork, payment, or another item but they do not specify what the drop off is for
Unless a caller specifies that the drop off is regarding an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle, or that the drop off is for the service, parts, collision, or body shop departments, then we cannot assume what the drop off is regarding and the call should be considered general.
Call is about the renewal of an existing lease
Call is about the rental of a vehicle or a loaner car
Caller is inquiring about a warranty, tags, or plates
Caller only asks about hours of operation for the business and does not specify a department of service, parts, collision, or body shop
If a caller specifies the sales department, but they only ask about hours of operation for the sales department, it does not represent an opportunity for the buying, selling, or trading of a vehicle and should be considered a general call.
Caller is returning a missed call but the call ends with neither caller nor business identifying the original caller or reason for the call
If a caller's sole inquiry is to identify the reason for a missed call, and they are told by the answering agent that the original caller or reason for the call cannot be identified, this is considered enough information to satisfy the caller's reason for calling. The caller needs no further information, nor needs any further connection to any agent or employee. Thus, the answering agent is qualified, and the call is considered handled.
Caller is returning a missed call but is not in the market to buy, sell, trade, or lease a vehicle
This will often sound like an agent asking a caller if he or she is interested in buying, selling, leasing, or trading in a vehicle, and the caller informing the agent that he or she is not in the market.
Calls should only be considered opportunities when the caller is in the market, regardless of if the agent mentioned a specific vehicle or attempted to encourage the caller to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle. When callers are not in the market, they do not represent business opportunities for the dealership.
Call is regarding a dealer trade
Dealer trades are not opportunities for a dealership to buy or sell a vehicle. Dealer trades, sometimes also referred to as dealer swaps, are when competing dealerships trade cars with each other, swapping similar cars to meet the demands of their customers. These are exchanges of vehicles only, and they do not represent buying or selling.
Caller is from a third-party company asking for information about a vehicle that a mutual customer is interested in
Calls from a third-party company, such as a finance company, may request vehicle information for their own business needs regarding the mutual customer. These third-party companies are not customers, and therefore should not be considered an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle.
Caller only refers someone to the dealership but does not themself represent an opportunity for the caller to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle
A referrer alone is not the customer. They are solely attempting to provide the dealership with information about a potential customer. A call should only be considered an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle once the actual customer and dealership connect.
Call is an agent-to-agent discussion about a mutual customer but does not represent an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle on behalf of the customer
Agent-to-agent discussions, regarding internal business for the dealership, do not themselves represent opportunities.
A call should only be considered an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle when the actual customer is the one involved in the discussion with dealership or when the agent involved is speaking on behalf of the customer with the intent to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle.
Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent
Call was not handled by a live, qualified employee/agent.
You can reference the instructions for the upstream category Inbound if you need assistance in understanding what qualifies as a call that is handled by a live, qualified employee/agent

Dealership Discussion is a category that reviews connected calls to determine what the caller is discussing with the dealership. Qualified agents can assist the caller with most or all of their inquiry, while unqualified agents cannot. Interactive systems and auto-attendants are considered connected calls if they handle the inquiry successfully. Opportunity to buy/sell/lease/trade a vehicle, inquiries about a vehicle of interest, and general interest in vehicle inventory are some of the options for this category. Service/parts/collision/body shop and general/caller not in the market/dealer trade are other options. Calls that are not connected to a live, qualified agent should be corrected.

Category Instructions: Dealership Discussion
The purpose of the category Dealership Discussion is to determine what the caller is discussing with the dealership.


Helpful information:
Connected calls:
Calls must be considered connected to be reviewed in this category. If the call does not qualify as connected, the correction option should be selected to remove the call from the category. A call is considered connected when the caller has either reached the desired agent or reached a qualified agent that can assist the caller.
Qualified agent:
A qualified agent is an employee that can assist a caller with most or all of his or her inquiry. The qualified agent may at times be too busy to handle the inquiry at the time of the call, or he or she may need to gather more information and call back to provide an answer or solution. These scenarios are still considered connected to a qualified agent if the same agent is the one intending to return the call.
Unqualified agent:
An unqualified agent is an employee that is not able to assist the caller with most or all of his or her inquiry either during that specific call or in a promised follow-up call from the same agent.
Interactive systems and auto-attendants:
Calls handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant will sound like interactive recordings that ask questions or request information and require the caller to interact by making phone selections. These can be either Connected or Not Connected.
When a call is successfully handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant it should be considered a connected call, and proper review selections should be made according to the content and outcome of the call.
When a caller leaves a call back number with the interactive system, instead of successfully handling their inquiry or need, then the call should be considered not connected.
Here are the options:
Opportunity to buy/sell/lease/trade a vehicle
Call represented an opportunity for the dealership to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle
The call does not have to include the mention of a particular make or model.
Some opportunities to buy, sell, lease, or trade may at times only mention vehicle specs. These should be listened to carefully to determine if there is an opportunity for the dealership to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle.
All calls that include a caller's interest in buying, selling, leasing, or trading a vehicle should be reviewed with this option, even if the vehicle is not currently available.
Caller inquiries about a vehicle of interest
This may include but is not limited to inquiries about vehicles seen online, in an advertisement, or from driving past the dealership's lot.
Caller expresses general interest in vehicle inventory
This may include but is not limited to inquiries regarding what vehicles are available that fit the caller's price range or what vehicles meet certain desired criteria.
Call is about payment or financing options for the purchase of a vehicle
This does not include calls regarding the financing of a vehicle that is already in the caller's possession.
Caller is inquiring about leasing a vehicle or is interested in a lease buyout
Caller would like to sell or trade a vehicle to the dealership
Caller is another dealership that represents an opportunity to buy or sell a vehicle
This does not include conversations about dealer trades. Dealer trades are not opportunities for a dealership to buy or sell a vehicle. Dealer trades, sometimes also referred to as dealer swaps, are when competing dealerships trade cars with each other, swapping similar cars to meet the demands of their customers. These are exchanges of vehicles only, and they do not represent buying or selling.
Service / parts / collision / body shop
Call is regarding automotive service
This may include but is not limited to service department hour inquiries, general service questions, service needs, service appointments, or inquiring about the status of a vehicle that is already being serviced by the dealership.
Call is regarding automotive parts
This may include but is not limited to parts department hour inquiries, general parts questions, part orders, or price and installation inquiries.
Call is regarding automotive collision or the body shop
This may include but is not limited to collision or body shop department hour inquiries, general collision or body shop questions, price and repair inquiries, and collision or body shop appointments.
General / caller not in market / dealer trade
Caller has general questions or a general conversation that does not represent an opportunity for the buying, selling, or trading of a vehicle
Caller is inquiring about the status of a vehicle order that has already been placed
Caller is inquiring about the delivery of a vehicle they have already purchased
Caller is from a transport company delivering a vehicle or multiple vehicles
Call is about financing and there was no opportunity for the buying, selling, or trading of a vehicle
Call is about the refinancing of a vehicle that is already in the caller's possession
Call is about the payments for a vehicle that is already in the caller's possession
Caller only states that they are coming to the dealership to drop off paperwork, payment, or another item but they do not specify what the drop off is for
Unless a caller specifies that the drop off is regarding an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle, or that the drop off is for the service, parts, collision, or body shop departments, then we cannot assume what the drop off is regarding and the call should be considered general.
Call is about the renewal of an existing lease
Call is about the rental of a vehicle or a loaner car
Caller is inquiring about a warranty, tags, or plates
Caller only asks about hours of operation for the business and does not specify a department of service, parts, collision, or body shop
If a caller specifies the sales department, but they only ask about hours of operation for the sales department, it does not represent an opportunity for the buying, selling, or trading of a vehicle and should be considered a general call.
Caller is returning a missed call but the call ends with neither caller nor business identifying the original caller or reason for the call
If a caller's sole inquiry is to identify the reason for a missed call, and they are told by the answering agent that the original caller or reason for the call cannot be identified, this is considered enough information to satisfy the caller's reason for calling. The caller needs no further information, nor needs any further connection to any agent or employee. Thus, the answering agent is qualified, and the call is considered handled.
Caller is returning a missed call but is not in the market to buy, sell, trade, or lease a vehicle
This will often sound like an agent asking a caller if he or she is interested in buying, selling, leasing, or trading in a vehicle, and the caller informing the agent that he or she is not in the market.
Calls should only be considered opportunities when the caller is in the market, regardless of if the agent mentioned a specific vehicle or attempted to encourage the caller to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle. When callers are not in the market, they do not represent business opportunities for the dealership.
Call is regarding a dealer trade
Dealer trades are not opportunities for a dealership to buy or sell a vehicle. Dealer trades, sometimes also referred to as dealer swaps, are when competing dealerships trade cars with each other, swapping similar cars to meet the demands of their customers. These are exchanges of vehicles only, and they do not represent buying or selling.
Caller is from a third-party company asking for information about a vehicle that a mutual customer is interested in
Calls from a third-party company, such as a finance company, may request vehicle information for their own business needs regarding the mutual customer. These third-party companies are not customers, and therefore should not be considered an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle.
Caller only refers someone to the dealership but does not themself represent an opportunity for the caller to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle
A referrer alone is not the customer. They are solely attempting to provide the dealership with information about a potential customer. A call should only be considered an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle once the actual customer and dealership connect.
Call is an agent-to-agent discussion about a mutual customer but does not represent an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle on behalf of the customer
Agent-to-agent discussions, regarding internal business for the dealership, do not themselves represent opportunities.
A call should only be considered an opportunity to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle when the actual customer is the one involved in the discussion with dealership or when the agent involved is speaking on behalf of the customer with the intent to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle.
Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent
Call was not handled by a live, qualified employee/agent.
You can reference the instructions for the upstream category Inbound if you need assistance in understanding what qualifies as a call that is handled by a live, qualified employee/agent

The purpose of the Dealership Discussion category is to categorize calls based on what the caller is discussing with the dealership. Connected calls must be considered for review, and correcting non-connected calls will remove them from this category. A qualified agent is an employee who can assist a caller with their inquiry, even if they need to gather more information and return the call later. Unqualified agents cannot assist a caller adequately. Calls handled by an interactive system or auto-attendant can be considered connected if they are handled successfully, and proper review selections should be made. The options for categorizing calls include opportunities to buy, inquiries about vehicles, and service/parts/collision/body shop calls. If a call was not handled by a live, qualified agent, select the Correction option. See the upstream category Inbound for further assistance on connected calls.

The Dealership Discussion category aims to identify the topic of conversation between the caller and the dealership. 

Important information:
Connected calls:
For a call to be reviewed under this category, it must be connected. If the call is not connected, select the correction option to remove it from the category. A call is considered connected when the caller reaches the desired agent, or a qualified agent capable of assisting the caller.
Qualified agent:
A qualified agent can assist the caller with most or all of their inquiries. Even if the agent is busy or needs to gather more information for a callback, the call is still considered connected to a qualified agent.
Unqualified agent:
An unqualified agent cannot assist the caller with most or all of their inquiries, either during the call or in a promised follow-up call.

Interactive systems and auto-attendants:
Calls handled by such systems may require the caller to interact by making phone selections. They can be considered Connected or Not Connected.

Options for call topics:
Opportunity to buy/sell/lease/trade a vehicle: The call represents an opportunity for the dealership to buy, sell, lease, or trade a vehicle, even if the vehicle is not currently available.

Caller inquiries about a vehicle of interest: The caller asks about vehicles seen online, in advertisements, or from driving past the dealership's lot.

Caller expresses general interest in vehicle inventory: The caller inquires about available vehicles that fit their price range or meet specific criteria.

Call is about payment or financing options for vehicle purchase: Excludes calls about financing a vehicle already in the caller's possession.

Caller inquires about leasing a vehicle or lease buyout; selling or trading a vehicle to the dealership; or another dealership representing an opportunity to buy or sell a vehicle (excluding dealer trades or swaps).

Service/parts/collision/body shop-related calls.

General/caller not in the market/dealer trade calls: Includes calls with general questions, vehicle order status inquiries, transport company representatives, financing unrelated to vehicle purchase, existing lease renewals, vehicle rentals or loaners, warranty/tag/plate inquiries, hours of operation inquiries, and calls regarding dealer trades or swaps.

Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent: The call was not handled by a qualified employee or agent.

The Dealership Discussion category aims to identify the topic of conversation between the caller and the dealership. 

Important information:
Connected calls:
For a call to be reviewed under this category, it must be connected. If the call is not connected, select the correction option to remove it from the category. A call is considered connected when the caller reaches the desired agent, or a qualified agent capable of assisting the caller.
Qualified agent:
A qualified agent can assist with most or all inquiries. Even if the agent is busy or needs to gather more information for a callback, the call is considered connected to a qualified agent.
Unqualified agent:
An unqualified agent cannot assist with most or all inquiries, either during the call or in a promised follow-up call.

Interactive systems and auto-attendants:
Handled calls may require the caller to interact by making phone selections. They can be considered Connected or Not Connected.

Options for call topics:
1. Opportunity to buy/sell/lease/trade: Represents an opportunity for the dealership to engage in transactions, even if the specific vehicle is not available.

2. Vehicle inquiries: The caller asks about vehicles seen online, in advertisements, or at the dealership's lot.

3. General interest in inventory: The caller inquires about available vehicles fitting their price range or meeting specific criteria.

4. Payment/financing options: Excludes calls about financing a vehicle already in the caller's possession.

5. Leasing, selling or trading: Inquiries about leasing a vehicle or lease buyout; selling or trading a vehicle to the dealership; or other dealerships looking to buy or sell vehicles (excluding dealer trades or swaps).

6. Service/parts/collision/body shop-related calls.

7. General/caller not in the market/dealer trade calls: Includes general questions, vehicle order status inquiries, transport company representatives, financing unrelated to vehicle purchase, existing lease renewals, vehicle rentals or loaners, warranty/tag/plate inquiries, hours of operation inquiries, and calls about dealer trades or swaps.

Correction: caller never connected to a live, qualified agent: The call was not managed by a qualified employee or agent.

Can you convert this text with instructions into a prompt for ChatGPT3 for to classify calls?

Option 1: 
- If the customer agreed to come to the dealership for a firm date and time appointment, select this option.
- If the customer agreed to come to the dealership for a loose date or time appointment, select this option.

Option 2: 
- If the customer is no longer in the market to buy a car, already sold or purchased a vehicle, or no longer has the vehicle of interest to trade, select this option.
- If the intended party hangs up before sharing whether or not he or she is interested, select this option.

Option 3: 
- If the customer is still in the market but didn't agree to come in, and there was no invitation by agent or caller to visit the dealership, select this option.
- If the interested party declined an appointment request, select this option.
- If the customer is still in the market but wants to wait to make a purchase, select this option.

Option 4:
- For any call that is unrelated to buying, selling, trading, or test driving, select this option.
- For calls that have been placed to follow up a previous purchase, select this option.
- For calls that have been placed to discuss an existing appointment, select this option.
- If the call is regarding the delivery of a previously purchased vehicle, select this option.
- If the call is regarding the pick-up of a previously purchased vehicle, select this option.

Classify the calls using the following categories:

Option 1:
- Select this when the customer agrees to come to the dealership for a scheduled appointment, whether it is a firm or loose date and time.

Option 2:
- Select this when the customer is no longer in the market to buy a car, has already sold or purchased a vehicle, no longer has the vehicle of interest to trade, or the intended party hangs up before sharing their interest.

Option 3:
- Select this when the customer is still in the market but didn't agree to come in, was not invited to visit the dealership, declined an appointment request, or wants to wait before making a purchase.

Option 4:
- Select this for calls unrelated to buying, selling, trading, or test driving, calls discussing a previous purchase or an existing appointment, or calls regarding the delivery or pick-up of a previously purchased vehicle.
